Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Advances in Tropical Dynamics; Honolulu, Hawaii; January 14-15, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for a workshop on the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) to be held January 14-15 2014 at the East-West Center (EWC) at the University of Hawaii. The MJO is an envelope of organized convection that propagates from the Indian Ocean to the Pacific Ocean and constitutes the dominant form of intraseasonal precipitation and atmospheric circulation variability in the tropics. The MJO influences a variety of tropical weather and climate phenomena,including tropical cyclones (affecting hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico), the onset and intraseasonal fluctuations of the monsoons and rainfall over Asia, Australia, Africa, and the Americas, and the onset of El Nino events. The goal of the workshop is to bring together the community of researchers engaged in MJO research to summarize the progress and remaining challenges in understanding the dynamics of the MJO, and to make plans for future coordinated numerical simulation experiments. More specifically, workshop participants will 1) discuss and synthesize recent theoretical, modeling, and diagnostic breakthroughs related to tropical dynamics; 2) survey remaining challenges and roadblocks to improving our understanding of tropical dynamics, and discuss the optimal paths forward for the community to address such challenges; and 3) update the status of the ongoing MJO aquaplanet intercomparison effort. A published paper summarizing the the workshop and "highlighting progress and future challenges" is an expected outcome of the workshop. The EWC is chosen as the venue for the workshop due to the expectation that about half of the workshop participants will come from Asia.

The funds provided through this award will support travel for about 10 graduate students and 5 postdocs, to be chosen through an open competition. Thus, this award will enable scientists at the earliest stages of their careers to meet and interact with the worldwide community of MJO researchers, and enable them to see cutting-edge results and research perspectives which may not be available to them at home. Aside from the scientific broader impacts associated with promoting international collaboration and supporting early-career scientists, the work has societal value in that it will advance understanding of the MJO, a phenomenon which has multiple societal impacts around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is an exciting time in the tropical meteorology field. Advances in our understanding of the tropics and improvements in modeling the tropics have led to significantly improved forecasts of hurricane activity and other severe weather at several weeks lead time. These advances can be used to improve forecasts that help protect life and property in regions across the United States, given the strong remote influence of the tropics on higher latitudes. Theoretical understanding of the tropics has also developed rapidly over the last decade to forge new directions in improving forecasts and projections of the tropics in climate and weather forecasting models. Understanding of variability in the tropics such as the Madden-Julian oscillation that remotely affects severe weather in the United States including West Coast flooding, heat waves, cold outbreaks, and droughts has rapidly improved. A tropical dynamics workshop was convened during January 14-16, 2014 to a) discuss and synthesize recent theoretical, modeling, and diagnostic breakthroughs related to tropical dynamics, to b) survey remaining challenges and roadblocks to improving our understanding of the tropics and ability to forecast aspects of the tropics such as hurricanes, and to c) discuss the optimal paths forward for the tropical meteorology community to address such challenges. The workshop involved participation from over 45 researchers from universities and national laboratories in the United States, Japan, South Korea, Canada, China, and the UK. 30% of the participants were students and postdoctoral researchers, which extends the goal of training the next generation of scientific researchers. A vibrant discussion of current progress in tropical dynamics was conducted, and future research directions were suggested.

 

The outcomes of the workshop suggested that future tropical meteorology research directions should provide increased emphasis in the following areas:

 

a) The processes by which tropical precipitation organizes into strong disturbances such as tropical storms, hurricanes, and the Madden-Julian oscillation needs to be better understood in models and observations. This includes a deeper examination of the processes that control water vapor in the tropics, and also how processes such as gust fronts affect the ability to organize strong tropical systems.

 

b) How the atmosphere and ocean interact to influence tropical meteorology and its remote impacts on the United States needs more emphasis.

 

c) The precise means by which hurricane formation occurs requires greater emphasis, given the importance of this understanding for improving forecasts of these damaging storms.

 

d) Novel ways of improving climate and weather forecast model simulations of the tropics need to be pursued given current deficiencies.
